Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The oldest object found in the Truman home by the National Park Service is a bronze Hindu bell-gong made in Korea, ca. 1400.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Five presidents visited the Truman home: Herbert Hoover, Lyndon Johnson, & Richard Nixon came to see Mr. and Mrs. Truman, and Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter visited Mrs. Truman after she was a widow.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The Truman home in Independence is approximately 975 feet above sea level. The Truman farm home in Grandview is approximately 1,060 feet above sea level. The mean elevation for Missouri is 800 feet.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman did not like “The Missouri Waltz.” “As far as music is concerned,” he said, “it’s as bad as ‘The Star Spangled Banner.’”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The Steinway baby grand piano in the Truman home was a present to Margaret Truman from her parents in 1932. This was during the Great Depression. Harry Truman probably paid around $1,000 for it.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The office of the vice president became vacant when Harry Truman succeeded to the presidency in 1945. The office remained vacant until Alban Barkley of Kentucky was elected as Harry Truman’s vice president in 1948.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The stained glass in the living room windows at the Truman home is really flashed glass. Flashed glass is a thin layer of colored glass applied to clear glass. It is less expensive than stained glass, but looks almost the same.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman hung his wife’s portrait in the Truman home parlor even though she objected. Mrs. Truman was not the type of person who liked to draw attention to herself.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s family moved to Independence in December, 1890, so Harry, his brother, and sister could attend graded schools.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman entered the first grade at Noland School in Independence in September 1892, and he and Bess Wallace graduated from Independence High School in May 1901.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: After graduating from high school, Harry Truman held several odd jobs in Kansas City including timekeeper on a railroad construction job, and a clerk/teller in two large Kansas City banks.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Bess Truman’s full name was Elizabeth Virginia Wallace Truman. Margaret Truman’s full name was Mary Margaret Truman. Her married name was Margaret Truman Daniel.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman didn’t want to embarrass his loved ones. He wrote, “I’ve never cared for social position or rank for myself except to see that those dear to me were not made to suffer for my shortcomings.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman vetoed the Taft-Hartley Act of 1947 on the basis that the Act was unfair to labor groups. Congress overrode his veto.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman signed the National Security Act of 1947, which created the Department of Defense and the Air Force, and established the National Security Council and the Central Intelligence Agency.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman urged legislation that would guarantee that each person, regardless of race, color, or national origin, would have access to equal opportunity in education, decent housing, and jobs, but the president met strong Congressional resistance.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman recognized the state of Israel on 14 May 1948. The Arab countries were not pleased. The next day, Arab armies invaded Israel and the first Arab-Israeli war began.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Jack Benny, Henry Fonda, Jackie Cooper, Eddie Fisher, Carl Reiner, Tippi Hedren, Barbara Rush, Joan Stanley, Maurice Chevalier, and Bob Hope are celebrities who visited the Trumans at their home.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The Soviet Union began the Berlin blockade in the hope that the Allies would be forced to abandon West Berlin. In response, President Truman ordered the Berlin airlift, which supplied West Berlin by air and lasted almost a year.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman issued an executive order declaring, “that there shall be equality of treatment and opportunity for all persons in the armed services without regard to race, color, religion, or national origin.' This marked the desegregation of the armed forces.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman signed the North Atlantic Treaty, which created NATO. The treaty committed each member state to consider an armed attack against one state to be an armed attack against all states.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: After an exhausting whistle-stop campaign, Harry Truman won reelection to the presidency in November 1948. A whistle-stop is a little town where infrequent train stops were signaled by a whistle.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman signed the Housing Act of 1949, which created the Urban Redevelopment Agency and gave it the authority to subsidize three fourths of the cost of local slum clearance and urban renewal.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: On 23 September 1949, President Truman announced that an atomic explosion had been detected in the Soviet Union. This meant the United States was no longer the only nation with an atomic bomb.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The Mutual Defense Assistance Act of 1949 promised assistance to any ally that might be attacked by the Soviet Union or one of its allies.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In December 1949, the Communist Party took control in China. The Chinese Nationalist government fled from the mainland of China to Formosa.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman stood 5 feet 10 inches tall and weighed 185 pounds when he became president, and 175 pounds during his last year in office.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman had blue eyes and brown hair that was mostly gray by the time he became president. He had a slow heartbeat and chronic low blood pressure. Otherwise, his health generally was sound.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman dressed fashionably in tailor-made suits. He was named one of the 10 best-dressed senators. He briefly owned a clothing store and, when he got married, his tailor was his best man.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: “To really understand Harry S Truman,” wrote his daughter, Margaret, “you must grasp the importance of humility in his thinking.” He was not the type of person to brag. “But,” continued Margaret, “this practice of humility never meant that Dad downgraded his worth, in his own mind.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman was not a dynamic speaker when delivering prepared speeches. He spoke with a flat Missouri twang and lacked the inspirational quality of Franklin Roosevelt. However, when speaking extemporaneously, Truman fired up crowds with simple, straightforward language and short sentences.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was of English, Irish, and German ancestry, and he claimed he was the great-great-great-nephew of President John Tyler.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Although his eyesight was correctable, Harry Truman was extremely nearsighted and wore eyeglasses from age six. His first pair cost $10.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was accident-prone as a child. When he was a little boy, he broke his collarbone when he fell off a chair while combing his hair.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In what some consider his bravest action, President Truman relieved General MacArthur of his command in 1951. MacArthur’s popularity soared temporarily, while Truman’s plummeted. Today, most people recognize the confrontation as an example of a president enforcing civilian control over the military.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The prime point of disagreement in Korean War peace talks was prisoner exchange. Some North Koreans didn’t want to be sent back, and this held up the return of South Korean & UN soldiers from prison camps in the North.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: A Constitutional amendment, passed during Truman’s administration, limited a president to no more than ten years in office, but Truman was exempt. He could have run again in 1952, but he chose not to do so.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman could have run for reelection in 1952, but chose not to. He wrote, “Eight years is enough and sometimes too much for any man to be the president of the United States.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: To prevent a strike during the Korean War, President Truman seized the nation’s steel mills. He felt he was within the limits of his wartime powers. The Supreme Court struck down Truman’s action, claiming his wartime powers did not apply; the nation, technically, had never declared war in Korea.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: After his retirement, Harry Truman claimed he wanted to spend his time teaching young people about their government. The Truman Library, which he opened in 1957, enabled him to do that.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In 2004, the NPS was authorized to acquire an additional five acres of land south of the Truman farm home in Grandview, thus increasing the size of Harry S Truman National Historic site to about 11 acres.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: On 4 February 1985, the Truman Farm Home was designated a National Historic Landmark, and in December 1993, Congress authorized the National Park Service''s acquisition of the Truman Farm Home from Jackson County, Missouri.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In October 1989, Congress authorized the National Park Service acquisition of the George P. Wallace home, the Frank G. Wallace home, the Noland home, and their associated grounds.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Ronald Regan signed the bill creating Harry S Truman National Historic Site on 23 May 1983, and the park opened to the public on 15 May 1984.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: On 8 December 1982, Secretary of the Interior James Watt proclaimed Harry S Truman National Historic Site under the authority of the 1935 Historic Sites Act.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Much of our modern world might be an entirely different place if Franklin Roosevelt’s previous vice president, Henry Wallace, had still been in office the day President Roosevelt died. Although not a communist himself, Wallace was endorsed by the Communist Party when he ran for president in 1948.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Mr. Truman is now viewed as a common citizen who lacked visions of grandeur, yet still rose to the nation’s highest level of power, without that power changing him.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: After his retirement from the presidency, President Truman had difficulty adjusting and accepting his diminished role in politics. He had to come to terms with the fact that it was no longer “his turn.”Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Through his letters and diary entries, it appears Mr. Truman, despite his presidential power, remained a relatively humble man throughout his life.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: His upbringing by his parents exerted a great deal of influence over Harry Truman’s behavior and beliefs. Nevertheless, he had the ability to separate his duties as president from some of his late-19th-century views.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: One of Harry Truman’s greatest motivations was to make those he cared about proud of him. Therefore, he was very conscious of his actions, and committed to doing a job right and to the best of his ability.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Having experienced the insecurities, hard work, and frustrations of managing a family farm and small business, many of Harry Truman’s actions as president reflect his empathy for the “little guy.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The self-reliance and common sense learned by Harry Truman during the time he lived on his grandmother’s farm prepared him to meet many of the numerous challenges that he would face as president.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Through Mr. Truman’s early letters, we can tell that most of the beliefs, philosophies, and values he expressed as a politician were already in place long before he dreamed of a life as a public servant.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman disliked the 22nd amendment, which prohibits the president from being elected more than twice. Truman felt presidents should honor the tradition set by George Washington and voluntarily retire. Truman testified on behalf of the unsuccessful repeal of the Amendment.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was a progressive farmer. He was attempting to stop erosion through contour plowing at least fifteen years before the first soil erosion laboratory in America was established in Missouri in 1929.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman took after his mother, while his brother, Vivian, was more like his father. While Harry was eager to play piano, Vivian said, “Mama wanted me to take piano lessons but she couldn’t get a lasso big enough.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was modest almost to the point of apology, which did nothing to inspire public confidence in him during the early stages of his administration.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman learned history during the “great man” period. It was a time when teachers hoped students would want to emulate the heroes they learned about.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In a poll of Washington correspondents conducted by 'Look' magazine, Senator Truman was named one of the 10 most valuable men in Washington in the war. He was the only member of congress among the ten.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was vice-president for 82 days. Only John Tyler and Andrew Johnson were vice-presidents for shorter periods.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman learned that, although he kept his word, not everyone else did so—especially Joseph Stalin. “Churchill had tried to get me not to withdraw our troops from Prague,” Truman said. “If I had known then what I know now, I would have ordered the troops to go to the western boundaries of Russia.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: There were three main reasons Franklin Roosevelt chose Harry Truman as a running mate in 1944: Truman’s personal loyalty and legislative support, his strong partisan background, and the fact he was from a Midwestern state.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s sympathies lay with the little guy unless the little guy became too powerful. Truman wrote, “The meanest person in the world is the underdog who gets to be top dog.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman believed that he had public support for the Korean War up until the 1952 campaign began. He said, “Every time you have a campaign, somebody has to be against something.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman said that the reason atomic bombs weren’t dropped beyond the Yalu River during the Korean War was because “we weren’t trying to start a war—we were trying to stop one.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Later in life, an interviewer asked Harry Truman, “When did you first realize you might be president?” Truman responded, “When I was nominated for vice president. That’s the reason I didn’t want the job.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman claimed FDR told him about the atomic bomb during their first conference after the ’44 election, but only that it was a tremendous explosive that might end the war. The details came after FDR’s death.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: It’s easy to collect a great many belongings when one is the President of the United States. It took one truck to move the Trumans into the White House in 1945. The President claimed that it took nine trucks to move him out in 1953.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s last car, a 1972 Chrysler Newport, still sits in his garage with less than 19,000 miles on it. His license plates read “5745”—May 7, 1945—the date of Germany’s surrender in WWII.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: While scientific facts can be tested, historic facts are more difficult to pin down. Harry Truman said, “You can have three different people watch an accident out here on the intersection and get three different versions about what happened.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry apparently never had a girlfriend other than Bess. After reading an anniversary letter from him, she teasingly wrote back, “It always amazes me how you can write such so-called love letters with such little practice.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was an optimist, a quality that later served him well as president. He wrote to Bess in 1912, “Nothing is so bad it couldn’t be worse.” About one financial plan, he wrote to her, “If I lose though I guess I’ll take a whack at something else. I can’t possibly lose forever.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was an optimist. In 1917, he wrote, “I seem to have a grand and admirable ability for calling tails when heads come up…. Still have high hopes on that, but then I’m naturally a hopeful, happy person….”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Although he was an optimist, Harry Truman sometimes became discouraged. In 1933, he wrote to Bess, “Tomorrow I’ll be forty-nine and for all the good I’ve done the forty might as well be left off….” Little did he know what his future held.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Upon the fall of the Pendergast machine, Harry wrote Bess, “Looks like everybody got rich in Jackson County but me. I can still sleep well even if it is a hardship on you and Margie for me to be so…poor.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was suspicious of hypocrisy in organized religion. He wrote to Bess in 1911, “I don’t think any church on earth will take you to heaven if you’re not real anyway.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry wrote to Bess in 1939, “In my opinion people’s religious beliefs are their own affair, and when I don’t agree with ‘em I just don’t discuss religion. It has caused more wars and feuds than money….”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s first car was a used 1911 Stafford he bought in 1914. Terry Stafford of Topeka made only about three hundred of the cars. Truman paid $600 for his. New, the cars sold for $2,350.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry wrote about his first car, “Getting sort of used to it I suppose – five thousand miles in three months is moving around somewhat…. Vivian [his brother] says I ought to sell the machine and buy cows with the money.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Throughout his career, Truman suffered from headaches & stomach trouble. The cause was always the same. He wrote to Bess, “I have the final report, and there is nothing the matter but fatigue….”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman credited Bess with his success in life. He wrote to her, “I might even have been a financial success if I’d started with you sooner.” “When a man gets the right kind of wife, his career is made – and I got just that.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman had little patience with self-proclaimed pundits. He wrote, “Senators and ex-Senators go to S[outh] A[merica], Germany, Japan, China, spend two or three days and know all about the countries and know all the answers. Guess I’m dumb.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was a joiner. He even tried to learn clarinet so he could play in the Grandview town band. The band knew only two or three tunes, but the leader would confuse audiences by using different names for the same song.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s mother was an opinionated woman. He wrote, “If my dear old mother has any fault, and I don’t agree that she has any, it is an inability to keep her personal likes and dislikes from the world at large.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was elected first lieutenant of his National Guard unit. The election of officers was common in the Civil War and lasted until the federalizing of National Guard units in 1917.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry and Bess referred to their daughter, Margaret, as “Marg,” “Margie,” and sometimes “Marger” – all pronounced with a hard “g.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman had the idea he needed to be rich before he could marry Bess. He wrote her, “I don’t think any man should expect a girl to go to a less comfortable home that she’s used to.” Also, “You’ve no idea how crazy I am about you and you won’t have until I get somewhat richer than at present.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was never a man given to excess. He wrote to Bess, “An ideal condition would be to have to work just enough so if you stopped you’d not go busted at once – but still you’d know if you didn’t work you couldn’t live.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry felt he should be financially sound before he proposed to Bess. He wrote, “They say it is bad luck to buy [a wedding] ring on time [i.e., credit] or with borrowed money, hence my long wait about getting it.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s loved ones were his inspiration. He wrote to Bess in 1951, “Please take care of yourself. I don’t think you fully understand that I can face the world and all its troubles if you and Margie are all right. I don’t think I can do it if you are not.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Young Harry Truman nearly choked to death on a peach pit. His mother saved his life by forcing the pit down his throat with her fingers.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: During their courtship, Harry wrote to Bess, “When I was very young I set a certain young lady up as my ideal and she’s still it, and will always be whether she wants to be or not, and you know who she was, is, and eternally will be.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry wrote to Bess during WWI, “I heard a Frenchman remark that Germany was fighting [the war] for territory, England for the sea, France for patriotism, and Americans for souvenirs.” Truman would often repeat this story later in life when souvenir hunters threatened to tear his house apart.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The submarine base at Key West—known as the Little White House—was protected by the Nary, and had room for 20 or 30 reporters, a staff of sixteen, and another fifteen or sixteen Secret Service men. The quarters were modest, but it was the ideal vacation home for President Truman.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: When he was a small boy, Harry Truman cut off the tip of his big toe when he slammed it in the cellar door. A doctor reattached it successfully.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: When Harry Truman was nine, he contracted a near-fatal case of diphtheria that paralyzed his arms and legs; he was pushed around in a baby carriage for several months until he regained the use of his limbs.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s mother taught him to read when he was five years old. Later, in school, he was a hardworking, though not a particularly brilliant, student. His favorite subjects were history and Latin.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Unable to afford college, Harry Truman hoped to obtain a free education by attending West Point or Annapolis, but his poor eyesight made it impossible.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was a Baptist. When it came to church, though, he claimed he was “more of a member than an attendant.” Nevertheless, he was well versed with the Bible and often sent reporters scurrying for their copies when he referred to Biblical passages during press conferences.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: For exercise, Harry Truman walked approximately two miles every morning at a rapid clip of 120 steps per minute, and, for recreation, he enjoyed low-limit poker.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s favorite pieces of music included Mozart’s Sonata No. 5, Beethoven’s Symphony Number Five, and Strauss’s “Blue Danube Waltz.” He also liked Chopin’s waltzes and Bach’s fugues.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s favorite artists were Holbein, Rubens, and Leonardo da Vinci. He detested the work of Picasso and other modern artists. He called it “ham and egg” art.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman did not smoke. However, he drank moderately, preferring bourbon. He also claimed to enjoy an occasional white wine with dinner.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman died in Research Hospital in Kansas City on 26 December 1972, from kidney failure and heart disease. The report called it “a complexity of organic failures resulting in collapse of the cardiovascular system.” He was 88 years old.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman is buried in the courtyard of the Truman Library. When he died in 1972, his estate was valued at about $600,000 (over 2.8 million in 2006 dollars).

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Bess Truman died in her home on 18 October 1982, from congestive heart failure. She was 97 years, 247 days old. As of 2014, she is the longest-lived First Lady of all time. She is buried with her husband in the courtyard of the Truman Library.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman said, “Three things can ruin a man—money, power, and women. I never had any money, I never wanted power, and the only woman in my life is up at the house right now.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: From George Washington through Harry Truman, when a man left the White House, he received no pension or protection. Both were instated during Truman’s retirement and he received them after that.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In January 1950, President Truman approved the development of the hydrogen bomb. This new “superbomb” would be 1,000 times more powerful than the atomic bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The square footage of the houses of Harry S Truman National Historic Site are as follows: Truman home, 8,861; Noland home, 2,199; Frank Wallace home, 2,192; Truman farm home, 1,915, & George Wallace home, 1,602.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Senator Joseph McCarthy was a thorn in President Truman’s side. In February 1950, the Senator announced that he had a list of names of Communists in the State Department. His charges were never proved, and the Senate censured him in 1954.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The most significant historical event to take place in the Truman home happened in June 1950. This was when President Truman received the telephone call alerting him that North Korea had attacked South Korea.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman said committing ground troops to Korea was his most difficult decision as president, while his biggest disappointment was his inability to overcome the organized opposition to a mandatory universal health care program.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The aspect of his administration that made him most proud, said Harry Truman, was the prevention of World War III, while he expected to be most remembered for the advent of the Cold War.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: China entered the Korean War in November 1950, almost overrunning the entire peninsula. General MacArthur’s troops were forced back in perhaps one of the worst defeats ever suffered by an American army.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry met Bess when he was six and she was five. It took him five years to get up the courage to speak to her, another fifteen years to call on her, and then he courted her for nine years while attempting to make his fortune.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: What is now called “the Truman home” in Independence was built by Bess Truman’s grandfather, George Porterfield Gates, about 1867 and was enlarged and remodeled in 1885.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry and Bess Truman were 35 and 34 years old when they married. They had been acquainted since Harry was six and Bess was five years old.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The farmhouse at the Truman farm in Grandview was built in 1894 to replace a larger structure that burned that same year. The smaller house was meant to be temporary, but soon became permanent.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was born on 8 May 1884 in a 20 x 28-foot cottage in Lamar, Missouri. His family moved from there before he was a year old. His birthplace is operated by the State of Missouri as a historic site.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: When Harry Truman lived there (1906-1917), his family’s farm was 600 acres in area. That was four times the size of the average Missouri farm at that time.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: When Mrs. Truman’s grandmother died in 1924, her will left her house to her son (Bess Truman’s uncle). Mrs. Truman’s mother purchased the house from him for $10,000 and owned it until her death in 1952.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry and Bess Truman’s only daughter, Margaret, was born 17 February 1924, four days after Mrs. Truman celebrated her 39th birthday.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry S Truman’s middle name was just that: S. It was not an abbreviation. Mr. Truman claimed he was given the S to honor both his grandfathers, Solomon Young and Anderson Shipp Truman.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman moved into his wife’s family home in Independence upon their marriage in 1919. The house remained their home until their deaths (Mr. Truman in 1972 and Mrs. Truman in 1982).

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman served in World War I from 1917-1919, rising to the rank of captain in the 129th Field Artillery of the Thirty-Fifth Division.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman married Bess Wallace on 28 June 1919 in the Trinity Episcopal Church in Independence. The weather was so hot, the flowers in the church wilted.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman owned and operated a haberdashery (men’s clothing store) in Kansas City from 1919 until 1922. Although the store did very well the first year, a depression later drove them out of business.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was elected eastern district judge of the Jackson County Court (an administrative body) on 7 November 1922. The “judges” were actually county commissioners and were not required to have law degrees.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s daughter, Margaret, was born on 17 February 1924 in a snowstorm. Her parents had not purchased a crib and Margaret spent her first few days sleeping in a dresser drawer.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was defeated for reelection as eastern district judge of the Jackson County Court on 4 November 1924. This was the only election he ever lost.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: During his two years out of politics (1925 and 1926), Harry Truman sold memberships for the Kansas City Automobile Club.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was elected presiding judge, Jackson County Court, in 1926 and reelected in 1930. This position today is called the County Executor. Most counties call the position County Commissioner.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was elected to the U.S. Senate in 1934 and reelected in 1940. He did not finish his second term because he resigned to run for the vice presidency.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The Truman Committee investigated private industries that had wartime contracts with the federal government. Estimates of money saved by the committee’s efforts range as high as $15 billion.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Roosevelt and Truman won the presidential/vice presidential election on 7 November 1944. Harry Truman was Franklin Roosevelt’s third vice president.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Franklin Roosevelt died on 12 April 1945, and Vice President Harry Truman took the oath as president. He had been vice president less than three months.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman announced Germany’s surrender in World War II (Victory in Europe Day) on 8 May 1945, his 61st birthday.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The first atomic bomb was successfully tested on New Mexico in 16 July 1945. Light from the blast was visible from nearly two hundred miles away.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Due to difficulties with the Soviet Union at the Potsdam Conference in 1945, President Truman and Prime Minister Winston Churchill suspected that the approaching end of World War II did not mean the end of world conflict.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The Senate ratified the UN charter on 28 July 1945. This was the first international organization in which the United States participated whose purpose was to settle disputes peacefully rather than by war.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The United States dropped two atomic bombs on Japan in early August 1945. After the second bomb was dropped, President Truman stopped the bombing program even though Japan had not yet surrendered.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman’s Fair Deal program recommended that all Americans be provided with health insurance, that the minimum wage be increased, and that, by law, all Americans be guaranteed equal rights.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman signed the Employment Act on 20 February 1946. The Act’s main purpose was to lay the responsibility of economic stability onto the federal government.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: During a railroad strike in 1946 that paralyzed the nation’s main transportation network, President Truman asked for legislation to draft the striking workers into the army.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: President Truman signed the Atomic Energy Act of 1946, which established the Atomic Energy Commission. The Act transferred the control of atomic energy from military to civilian hands.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The Truman Doctrine of 1947 was instrumental in helping prevent Turkey and Greece from becoming part of the Soviet Union.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Due to the lack of a direct train route, the 20-mile trip between Grandview and Independence during Harry Truman’s courtship with Bess took two hours one way.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: While Harry Truman fought in France, the influenza epidemic of 1918 caused perhaps ten times as many American deaths in two or three months as did WWI itself. Soldiers, defending their country in Europe, were frustrated, knowing loved ones were dying at home of illness.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman always identified with the little fellow. He wrote to Bess in 1911, “You’ve no idea how experience teaches sympathy.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s first nephew was born in 1913, and became the center of family attention. Always the practical one, Harry wrote to Bess, “I never could rave over the beauty of babies because to my notion they all look alike, unless there’s something radically wrong with them.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was almost naively honest. He wrote to Bess in 1914, “When I buy a cow for $30 and then sell her to someone for $50 it always seems to me that I am really robbing that person of $20.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Although known as “Give ‘em Hell Harry” on the campaign trail, Harry Truman was a very sensitive and generous person. He wrote to Bess in 1919, “You’ve no idea how I hate to call a man down.”Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The world changed a lot during Truman’s life. He wrote to Bess, “These young kids can’t stand the physical and mental inconveniences that the old heads take as a matter of course…. They all live in a machine-convenience age and when the machine doesn’t function for them they are out of luck.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Farming is hard work and requires physical strength. Harry Truman wrote to Bess in 1912, “A two-hundred-pound hog can almost jerk the ribs loose from your backbone when you get him by the hind leg.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s life was one of opportunity along with risk. He wrote Bess in 1913, “There’s always something wrong with a crop. It’s either too dry or too wet or too short or too long or too much or not enough. ''If'' is the largest word in a farmer’s language.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In Harry Truman’s first proposal to Bess (by letter), he wrote about the lack of rain making water and potatoes as rare as pineapples and diamonds. He continued, “Speaking of diamonds, would you wear a solitaire on your left hand should I get it?” She gently turned him down, but later accepted.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: From age six on, Harry was always interested in Bess. He later wrote her, “I have never met a girl in my life that you were not the first to be compared with her, to see wherein she was lacking and she always was.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: During their courtship, Harry wrote to Bess, “I’m horribly anxious for you to suffer from an excessively good opinion of me!” This desire to please her continued throughout his life and played a large part in determining his behavior as president.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman held women in high esteem. He wrote to Bess, “You know, I’ve always thought that the best man in the world is hardly enough for any woman.” Soon after their engagement, he wrote her, “You’ll never be sorry if you take me for better or worse because I’ll always try to make it better.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was a practical romantic. He wrote to Bess that, even though he wanted to, he couldn’t “rescue you from any monster or carry you from a burning building or save you from a sinking ship – simply because I’d be afraid of the monsters, couldn’t carry you, and can’t swim.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Bess provided Harry with motivation. He wrote her in 1914, “When the finest girl in all the world has faith in a fellow’s ability to win, he’s simply got to do it, that’s all.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: During their courtship, Harry wrote to Bess, “I’ve almost come to the conclusion that it’s not intended for me ever to be very rich, nor very poor, and I am about convinced that that will be about the happiest state a man can be….”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: On her 52nd birthday, Harry wrote Bess, “I wanted to be there so badly to help you celebrate I don’t know how to express it.” Then he teased, “If your new dress doesn’t fit you, send it back and we’ll get a larger one.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman wanted to shine in the eyes of those he held dear. He wrote to Bess in 1942, “I’ve wanted so badly to make good in the Senate so you and [Margaret] wouldn’t be ashamed of me.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman believed he was related to President John Tyler, but current scholarship has cast doubt on that claim. His grandmother was Nancy Tyler Holmes, but there appears to be no connection between this Tyler and the man who succeeded to the presidency upon the death of William Henry Harrison.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman’s containment policy meant an acceptance of a divided world in which the East and the West were involved in a conflict of indefinite length between the forces of communism and freedom.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman’s containment policy meant the willingness of the United States to oppose the Soviet Union whenever and wherever necessary, and by every means, including the risk of war.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman chose to fight the Cold War by rebuilding the West’s defenses to surpass that of the Soviet world, and of meeting each Communist challenge quickly and unequivocally.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: When the Korean War began, the US army numbered 592,000 men, less than one-half what it had been on Pearl Harbor Day. All American divisions lacked the equipment, training, and the mental preparedness required for combat.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: General MacArthur was unable to understand a war to restrain an invader rather than to annihilate him, “a war of limited objectives against a secondary enemy to avoid unlimited war against a primary enemy.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: General MacArthur was the first great commander to be bound by a new military concept: a limited war. Both he and part of the public had difficulty understanding that concept, but others, such as President Truman, felt atomic weapons had made all-out war too dangerous.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Communism is more frightening because of its largely unseen influence. It was this threatening ambiguity and the unfocused fear that went with it that defined Harry Truman’s administration.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Faced with the difficulty of finding a viable Democratic candidate in 1952, Harry Truman considered running for another term. Those close to him—and more importantly, Mrs. Truman—were against the idea. Mr. Truman said he guessed that made it unanimous; he would go back to Independence instead.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: About presidential power, Harry Truman said, “When there’s too much efficiency in government you’ve got a dictator. And it isn’t efficiency in government we’re after, it’s freedom in government.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: About presidential power, Harry Truman said, “You can’t have too strong an executive in the White House because his term is limited. You can always put him out if he gets too big for his breeches.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: About human nature, Harry Truman said, “In reading the lives of great men, I found that the first victory they won was over themselves and their carnal urges. Self discipline with all of them came first.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: About presidential decisions, Harry Truman said, “The country has never suffered seriously from the acts of a great president, but it has suffered by the inactions of a great many presidents.”Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: About presidential decisions, Harry Truman said, “Presidents have to make decisions if they’re going to get anywhere, and those presidents who couldn’t make decisions are the ones that caused trouble.”Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: About presidential decisions, Harry Truman said, “Nobody—remember this—nobody knows all the facts on which a president makes his decisions.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman understood people. About Woodrow Wilson, he said, “Wilson was smarter than anybody else and he knew it and he let them know it. You can’t do that when you’re running a government.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman returned from Washington with so many truckloads of belongings he told a reporter he thought it would take three months to find his socks and ties. He placed many of these items in the Truman Library.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman’s performance rating dropped to 23 percent in November 1951, one point lower than President Richard Nixon’s lowest rating.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Although Truman authorized the use of atomic weapons in Japan, he refused to do so again in Korea. Truman said, “[The atomic bomb] should not be used on innocent men, women, and children who have nothing whatever to do with this military aggression.”Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman refused to use atomic weapons in Korea, partly because he feared that an unexploded warhead could fall into the enemy’s hands and be used against the United Nations.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Margaret Truman gave her parents their first TV in the 1950s. Her father referred to it as the “television machine.” The color TV in the Trumans’ parlor was a gift from Margaret in 1970. No chairs face in its direction, a clear sign that they seldom watched it.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In search of land to build his library, Truman originally planned to return to Grandview rather than Independence after leaving the White House. The City of Independence, however, donated property for the building, so he decided not to move.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman’s low approval rating near the end of his term reflected the public’s dissatisfaction with three main things: The Korean war, charges of communism in government, and charges of corruption in the administration.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was an ordinary man, but not an average man. He was an ordinary man in the sense that he was not born into a position of wealth or influence. His becoming president, however, suggests he was anything but average.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s greatest strength lay in his ability to do the best he could with what he had and not to worry over what he did not have. He also never looked back with regret on situations or events he could not change.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman learned many things from his parents, including doing what has to be done the best one can and doing it without remorse or self-pity. He was not the type of person who felt sorry for himself.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s story is not average, but it is symbolic. It provides us with another example of a little boy, born into ordinary circumstances, who grows up to be the president of the United States.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was a modest man, but that did not mean he felt inferior to others. It did not hurt his pride to avail himself of the advice of experts in the fields of diplomacy, economics, and military affairs with which he had to deal.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: For some people, it was easy to underrate Truman. His frivolity, his coarseness, and his rustic and unrefined wit gave some the mistaken idea that he lacked commitment to and reverence for the office he held.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman, a man of unimpeachable personal integrity and political honor, was able to maintain an association and reliance upon the Pendergast machine without being corrupted by it.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: During WWII, eighty-five million men were involved in the war effort. Fourteen million were killed, 251,000 of them Americans — more combat deaths than in all the wars fought since 1793.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman joined the National Guard in 1905 at age 21. He served two 3-year terms. Later, in the army reserves, he was eventually promoted to major, and, by the mid-''thirties, was a full colonel.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman was partner in an oil company before WWI. They sunk what they thought was a dry well in Kansas, but what later proved to be the famous Teter Pool; had they drilled a bit more, Truman would have been a millionaire.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman loved music. He wrote to Bess in 1911, “Did you ever sit and listen to an orchestra play a fine overture and imagine that things were as they ought to be and not as they are?”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: A favorite Truman getaway was the 'Little White House' at Key West Naval Station in Florida. It was an ideal place to escape the pressures of Washington. He could fish, enjoy the sun, play poker, and get plenty of rest.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The Harry S Truman Little White House in Key West, Florida was built in 1890 as the first officer''s quarters on the naval station. In the beginning of the 20th century, the home was converted into a single family dwelling to house the base commandant.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman’s Key West home has hosted many distinguished guests. Thomas Edison stayed here during WWI, while working on depth charge research. Eisenhower used the home while recuperating from a heart attack in 1956. In 1961, Kennedy & Prime Minister MacMillan stayed here during the Bay of Pigs incident.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman’s Little White House remained a living quarters for the commanding officers of the base until Truman Naval Station was closed in 1974.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman liked the Little White House in Key West so well that he spent 175 days there during his nearly eight years as president.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The last time anyone slept in the Truman home was during the time of Mrs. Truman’s funeral, 18-24 October 1982. The residents were Margaret Truman Daniel, her husband, and four sons.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman never farmed a day in his life before he moved to his grandmother’s farm when he was 22 years old. Many of the other farmers first viewed him as a “city slicker.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: The atmosphere at the presidential retreat in Key West was always relaxed. The President handed out cards that read: DON’T GO AWAY MAD…JUST GO AWAY. Ice water got poured on anyone unwary enough to lie on the beach with their eyes closed. And loud Hawaiian shirts were the dress code of the day.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Bess Wallace was the oldest of four children born to David and Madge Wallace. Her three younger brothers were Frank, George and Fred.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman is the last president of the United States—and the only one in the 20th century—who did not earn a college degree.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Starting in November 1946, President Truman took the first of eleven vacations in Key West, Florida. He stayed at the Little Summer White House, a naval submarine station. Later, he made four visits to the Key West base as a private citizen. The Little Summer White House is open to the public.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman was pleased with his presidential vacation home in Key West. During his first visit, he wrote his mother & sister, “I left Washington yesterday morning in a rain and a fog with the temperature at 40. Arrived here at 3 p.m. in sunshine and 80. [M]y cough and cold are nearly gone already.”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Truman wrote in his memoirs, “I do not know of any easy way to be President. It is more than a full-time job and the relaxations are few. I used …the Little White House at Key West, less for holiday uses than as [a]hideaway…. [It] was very useful when I wanted to catch up on my work....”

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In the summer of 1940, the recently elected anti-Pendergast county officials foreclosed on the Grandview farm, forcing Harry Truman’s mother and sister off the property. Neither Senator Truman nor his brother had enough money to stop the proceedings.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: In the summer of 1940, the recently elected anti-Pendergast county officials foreclosed on the Grandview farm, forcing Harry Truman’s mother and sister off the property. Neither Senator Truman nor his brother had enough money to stop the proceedings.

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: By 1917, 33-year-old Truman was in the midst of World War I, as an officer in the U.S. Army. 'Captain Harry' inspired his troops in France with his courage and determination.Harry S Truman National Historic Site, Missouri

Park Name: Harry S Truman National Historic Site
Fact: Harry Truman was known for his neat appearance. Double-breasted suits, Stetsons and spectator shoes were his trademark. He took few risks, except for a few splashy neckties. That is, until he started vacationing in Key West and discovered the tropical sports shirt
The young fronds of the `ama`u fern (Sadleria cyatheoides) often emerge red to block harmful rays from the sun. They gradually turn green with age.
The two types of Hawaiian lava differ in appearance but are chemically alike. Pahoehoe has a smoother and ropey surface where a`a is jagged and clinkery.
The endangered Honu (Green Sea Turtle) are frequently seen in shallow waters and basking in the sun on beaches. They return to the Northwest Hawaiian Islands to lay their nests, over 700 miles away.

`A`ali`i (Dodonaea viscosa) is an important shrub with many traditional Hawaiian uses. Its hard and durable wood makes a fine spear. Seed pods are fashioned into beautiful lei, while its red capsules can be boiled to make dye.
During the 1800''s, vast quantities of fragrant sandalwood were the first major export of the Hawaiian Islands. The trade nearly caused the extinction of `iliahi or sandalwood (Santalum paniculatum).
Only two butterflies found in Hawai`i are native. The Kamehameha Butterfly (Vanessa tameamea) is Hawai`i''s state insect, brightly colored, and larger than the Blackburn''s blue (Udara blackburni).

Kilauea Volcano has erupted lava almost continuously from its east rift zone since 1983. These lava flows have added about 500 acres of new land to the southern shore of Kilauea and covered 8.7 miles (14 km) of highway with lava as deep as 115 feet (35 m).

As Secretary of Commerce in 1927, Herbert Hoover was the first person to appear on an intercity television broadcast. When television became more widespread, Hoover didn''t watch it much except to see baseball games.
General Land Office surveyors who first came to Iowa commented that the territory was fit only for waterfowl. Eighty-five percent of Iowa used to be soggy tallgrass prairie.
Herbert Hoover was the first person born west of the Mississippi River to become president. Seven other presidents were born west of the river.
President Hoover''s doctor designed an athletic game to keep him fit. 'Hooverball' is similar to volleyball, but scored like tennis. Players heave a six-pound medicine ball over the net.

In 1874, the year Herbert Hoover was born, Ernest Shackleton (an early Antarctic explorer), Honus Wagner (one of the greatest baseball players in history), Harry Houdini (a famous professional magician), and Robert Frost (Pulitzer Prize winning poet) were also born.
Herbert Hoover''s vice president Charles Curtis was of almost half American Indian ancestry. Curtis’ mother was one quarter Kaw, one quarter Pottawatomie and one quarter Osage.
The West Branch Schoolhouse was built in 1853 making it the oldest building at Herbert Hoover National Historic Site. The town''s Quakers also used the one-room building as their first meetinghouse.
Herbert Hoover''s birthplace was a tourist attraction as early as 1928. Jennie Scellers, the house''s owner, charged 10 cents for tours and set up a souvenir stand on her lawn.

In Herbert Hoover’s 31-year retirement from the presidency he never had any Secret Service protection. Not until 1965, one year after Hoover died, was lifetime Secret Service protection awarded to ex-presidents.
Herbert Hoover was an avid fisherman. He''d often don a jacket, tie, and hat along with his waders and gear while fly-fishing. 'All men are equal before fish,' he wrote.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Sir Walter Raleigh made England’s first serious attempts to settle North America. He launched three expeditions; the third was John White’s Roanoke Island settlement, often called 'the Lost Colony.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: In 1606, an English joint stock company was formed to establish settlements on the east coast of North America. This company included The Virginia Company of London (which founded Jamestown) and The Virginia Company of Plymouth (which established Popham, a short-lived settlement in Maine).

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: English settlers were encouraged to plant mulberry trees to help their silk production attempts. (Silkworms eat mulberry leaves.) Red mulberry is native to North America but the silkworms preferred the white mulberries of the Orient. Today Jamestown has both red and white mulberry trees.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: The botanical sassafras was at one time worth its weight in gold as a medicinal plant. It was an early Jamestown export. In modern times it has been used to flavor root beer.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Dendrochronology, the study of tree rings, indicates the Jamestown colonists arrived during the worst drought period in over 800 years for the lower Chesapeake Bay area of Virginia.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Captain John Smith produced a dictionary of over 500 Powhatan Indian words. Opossum, raccoon, persimmon and Chesapeake are all Powhatan Indian words.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Clay Pipe stems and bowls discarded by Jamestown settlers can help date an archeological site. Over 50,000 have been found by archeologists at Jamestown.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: The only known drawing of James Fort, known as the Zuniga Map, was obtained by the Spanish Ambassador in England who was spying on the Jamestown colony.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Wells are great places to find artifacts because when they were no longer used they became the “trash cans” for the settlers. Archaeologists have excavated shoes, armor, swords, Flagons, pottery, various animal bones and many other items from the wells of Jamestown.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: The common dandelion, buttercup and white clover we see in Virginia today originally came from Europe.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Of the first 104 English settlers at Jamestown in 1607, four were boys. Several boys were sent to live with the Powhatans so they could learn the language and customs and then return to the English to become interpreters.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Before the English arrived in Virginia in 1607, one of Powhatan’s priests predicted that he and the Powhatan people would be conquered by a people who came from the east.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Sturgeon are a prehistoric fish that have been around since dinosaurs roamed the earth. The colonists at Jamestown wrote that the rivers “swarmeth” with sturgeon.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Sturgeons have five rows of bony plates, called scutes, covering the head and body. These scutes are often found in the excavation of James Fort; the abundance of scutes in the archeological record supports the historical record.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Atlantic Sturgeon were over-fished in the 1890’s,coupled with a decline in water quality,the population is now greatly reduced;Atlantic Surgeon are now a protected species. The James River is the only river in the Chesapeake region with a confirmed breeding population.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: The bald eagle is the only eagle unique to North America. Its Latin scientific name, Haliaeetus leucocephalus, means sea (halo) eagle (aeetos) with a white (leukos) head (cephalus).

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: A bald eagle’s feathers are lightweight, yet strong and flexible. The birds approximately 7,000 feathers provide waterproofing and protect it from extreme temperatures by trapping layers of air.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: The bald eagles hollow-boned skeleton accounts for only five or six percent of its total body weight; its feathers weigh twice that amount.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: Before European settlement began in North America, bald eagles numbered an estimated half a million, enough for there to be a nest located along every mile of the Chesapeake Bay shoreline.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: The wingspan of a bald eagle can reach seven feet; mature eagles weigh ten to twelve pounds and measure about three feet from head to tail. Females are usually slightly larger than males.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: There are eleven Virginia Indian tribes recognized by the Commonwealth of Virginia. They are: the Mattaponi, the Pamunkey, the Chickahominy, the Eastern Chickahominy, the Upper Mattaponi, the Nansemond, the Rappahannock, the Monacan, the Patawomeck, the Cheroenhaka (Nottoway), and the Nottoway.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: The Pamunkey and Mattaponi are the only Virginia Indian tribes who own reservation lands. The lands were granted by treaties signed with the English in 1646 and 1677. The tribes still make the yearly tribute payment of fish and game - now to the Virginia Governor - as stipulated by those treaties!

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: No Virginia Indian tribes have federal recognition. The normal way – petitioning the Bureau of Indian Affairs – cannot be taken because of Walter Plecker’s 'paper genocide' in the 1900s. Since the 1990s, six of the state-recognized tribes have been trying to get it through an Act of Congress.

Park Name: Historic Jamestowne Part of Colonial National Historical Park
Fact: The land the English settled in 1607 was already home to more than thirty Powhatan Indian tribes. Each tribe had its own chief (weroance/weroansqua) who was “ruled” by paramount chief (mamanatowick) Powhatan. This Powhatan Chiefdom spanned all of tidewater Virginia and parts of the Eastern Shore.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: Eleanor Roosevelt, along with Louis Howe, was instrumental in getting FDR back into politics after he contracted polio in 1921.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: Eleanor Roosevelt married FDR on March 17,1905 ( St. Patrick''s Day ) in NYC. Her uncle President Theodore Roosevelt walked her down the aisle.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: Eleanor Roosevelt''s birth name was Anna Eleanor Roosevelt. She was the fifth cousin of Franklin and the niece of Teddy.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: Eleanor and Franklin Roosevelt had six children. 5 of them survived to adulthood, the oldest a daughter, Anna, and four sons, Elliot, James, Franklin Jr., and John.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: FDR did some of his famous fireside chats used to inform Americans of the progress of the country at the FDR Presidential Library and Museum on the FDR site.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: In 1945, the 'Big Three' Allied leaders Churchill, Roosevelt and Stalin met at Yalta in the Soviet Crimea to discuss strategy to end World War II. This became known as the Yalta Conference.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: Eleanor Roosevelt''s father, Elliot Roosevelt was the brother of President Theodore Roosevelt. Eleanor (pictured in the middle) was one of three children. She had two brothers, Elliot and Hall.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: FDR and his fifth cousin Teddy Roosevelt both went to Harvard, were Assistant Secretary of the Navy and Governor of New York State before becoming President of the United States.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: Eleanor Roosevelt, along with Louis Howe, was instrumental in getting FDR back into politics after he contracted polio in 1921.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: President Harry Truman was on hand at Springwood to help dedicate the Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt to the National Park Service in 1946.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: FDR named his Scottish Terrier Fala, 'Murray the Outlaw of Fala Hill' in honor of an outlaw Roosevelt ancestor whose home was Fala Hill in Scotland.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: Eleanor Roosevelt, along with Louis Howe, was instrumental in getting FDR back into politics after he contracted polio in 1921.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: Some of FDR''s hobbies as a boy were building model ships, birdwatching, and collecting coins and stamps.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: FDR designed Top Cottage (Originally called Dutchess Hill Cottage and Hilltop Cottage) in a way that would make it accessible to him in his wheelchair.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: In 1940, President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the enabling legislation for the Vanderbilt Mansion in Hyde Park, NY to become part of the National Park Service.

Park Name: Home Of Franklin D Roosevelt National Historic Site
Fact: President Franklin D. Roosevelt often referred to himself as a Tree Farmer and he listed it as his occupation.
Under the Homestead Act, 270 million acres of land, or 10% of the nation, was given away. That''s as big as California and Texas put together.
The Homestead Act of 1862, which gave away 160 acre claims, was repealed in the lower 48 states in 1976. In Alaska, claims could be filed up to 1986!
Women were allowed to claim 160 acres of land under the Homestead Act, 60 years before they earned the right to vote.
The Homestead Act, Emancipation Proclamation and the Railroad Act were passed at the same time and worked together to move emigrants to the west for settlement.
The Homestead Act of 1862 changed the world with its offer of free land. Millions of people immigrated to America seeking their fortune, shifting populations along with the power of governments.
During the height of the Homesteading era, Ellis Island was established to process the millions of people immigrating to America to acquire land.
To 'Prove up' a homestead, the owner was required to make improvements including building a home, breaking the soil, and planting a crop for 5 years.
While plowing 1 acre of ground, the homesteader walked 10 miles. So to plow the required 10 acres for his homestead, the homesteader had to walk a minimum of 100 miles.
Volunteers give over 27,000 hours of service to Homestead National Monument of America each year. If you would like to join, contact Susan Cook at 402-223-3514.
The Freeman School, which operated from 1872 to 1967, was wired for electricity in 1940. The first electric bill was $0.75.
The site was discovered by volunteers from the Japanese Cultural Center of Hawai`i in 2002.

Obsidian has been found at a few Hopewell earthwork sites. The majority of obsidian, several hundred pounds, was found in one mound at Hopewell Mound Group. Much of the obsidian is from Obsidian Cliff in Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming - over 1,500 miles away.
William Mills documented the presence of 49 enclosures and 370 mounds in Ross County in his book entitled 'Archaeological Atlas of Ohio,' published in 1914.

The first publication of the Smithsonian Institution in 1848 was an extensive survey of archeology sites that included all of the sites at Hopewell Culture NHP. The book was authored by Ephraim Squier (left) and Edwin Davis (right), residents of the town of Chillicothe where Hopewell Culture NHP is

People of the Hopewellian Culture made extensive use of copper from the Lake Superior region, near the Keweenaw peninsula and Isle Royal area. Copper was worked into elaborate objects and effigy artwork without using smelting techniques.

Freshwater mussels were an important resource for Hopewellian people. They were used as food, provided pearls for ornaments and shells were utilized for hoes. Although plentiful during the Middle Woodland period, over-harvesting and low water quality have reduced their numbers drastically today.
In 1918 Capt. Dwight D. Eisenhower (future President) visited Camp Sherman, a World War I training camp located in part, on the grounds of the Mound City Group.

British soldiers captured during the Battle of Lake Erie during the War of 1812 were marched to a prisoner of war camp (Camp Bull) located between the present day Mound City Group visitor center, and the northern part of the city of Chillicothe.

The smallest living carnivore uses the grounds at Hopewell Culture National Historical Park for hunting and nesting. Least weasels mainly prey on meadow voles, but will dine on shrews, moles, birds, and insects.

The term 'Hopewell' derives from the farm where excavations of an earthwork site (Hopewell Mound Group) occurred in 1891-1892 under the direction of Warren K. Moorehead. The property was owned by a local dry goods merchant and former Confederate Army soldier, Mordecai Cloud Hopewell.

Camp Sherman, a World War I training camp, was located in part at Mound City Group. Most of the mounds were significantly impacted. During construction of the cantonment, a new barrack was erected every 20 minutes.

Established on March 2nd, 1923 as Mound City Group National Monument, the park was the first federally created National Park Service site in Ohio. President Warren G. Harding, a native of Ohio, established the national monument using powers granted to him under Section 2 of the 1906 Antiquities Act

Men known as 'Fillers' worked 12 hour shifts 7 days a week entering 400 - 500 lbs. of iron ore, 30 - 40 lbs. of limestone and 15 bushels of charcoal every half hour into Hopewell''s furnace to keep it in 'blast'.

Charcoal, sometimes still smoldering from its recent manufacture, was first placed under the 'Cooling Shed' and allowed to lower in temperature before being shoveled into the 'Charcoal House'. This helped guard against accidental fire that could consume all of Hopewell Furnace''s fuel.

The term 'Cold Blast' refers to air being drawn directly from the outside atmosphere and entered into a furnace by its bellows machinery. A 'Hot Blast' system pre-heated the air before entry, a more efficient means of increasing temperature in a furnace. Hopewell Furnace was a cold blast furnace.

The owners of Hopewell Furnace built tenant houses for workers and their families coming from outside the immediate area. These dwellings were rented at the low rate of 1 to 2 dollars a month, as a perk or benefit to entice the best iron workers to come to Hopewell.
The production of cast iron stoves was a mainstay of Hopewell Furnace''s operations until 1844. The highpoint of Hopewell''s production was in 1839 when 5,152 stoves were produced.

An iron 'Molder' was one of the most skilled and best paid workers in the early iron industry. The best paid iron molder at Hopewell Furnace in 1836 was John Sheeler. He was paid $434.83 for producing enough cast iron stove plates to make 352 1/2 stoves.

While England passed laws to keep her American colonies from becoming economically independent, by 1775 no fewer than 22 furnaces (including Hopewell Furnace) operated in Southeastern Pennsylvania alone.

Slag was the waste material created during Hopewell Furnace''s iron smelting process. It consisted of residual minerals in the iron ore that remained after the iron had been removed. Often it appears glassy and multicolored, a combination of minerals such as copper, nickle and manganese.

Cold blast charcoal-fired iron furnaces like Hopewell Furnace were in operation in Pennsylvania as early as 1720. Between 1832 and 1840, 32 such furnaces were built in the state. The U.S. census of 1840 recorded 212 charcoal-fired furnaces operating in Pennsylvania that year.

Charcoal was the fuel used to fire early iron furnaces like Hopewell. Entered along with iron ore and limestone, the burning charcoal inside the furnace produced temperatures as high as 3000 degrees. The resulting hot metal would be fluid enough to pour into sand molds to make 'cast iron' products.

Iron, like that made at Hopewell Furnace, was the principal metal for use in most applications during the 18th and most of the 19th centuries. Only after the development of large scale production of steel through the Bessemer process did steel overtake iron as the common metal in most products.
Early iron works depended on large stands of forests to produce their fuel. The Hopewell Furnace consumed approximately one acre of woodland (converted into charcoal) per day of iron production.

Hardwood trees produced the highest quality and quantity of charcoal to fuel early ironworks. Chestnut was the principal tree of the forest surrounding Hopewell Furnace, and along with Oak, Hickory, Maple and Walnut trees, were harvested by the thousands each year to fuel the furnace.
By 1789 the Hopewell Furnace was Pennsylvania''s second largest producer of iron. Its stated capacity was 700 tons of iron per blast year. A 'blast year' usually lasted 10 - 11 months.

Hopewell Furnace produced products for not only common Americans but also foreign persons of note. In 1822 Hopewell received an order for a stove from Joseph Bonaparte, brother of Napolean Bonaparte, and the former appointed King of Spain.

It is believed that at the beginning of the American Revolution, furnaces in England''s American colonies were producing 15% of the world''s production of iron, more than England herself. Hopewell Furnace began production in 1771, four years before the outbreak of the revolution.

Hopewell Furnace was built initially to supply nearby forges operated by its builder, Mark Bird. The forges heated and hammered the furnace''s brittle pig iron bars, driving out much of their contaminate carbon and turning the metal into stronger, more malleable wrought iron.

Early in the American Revolution, colonial ordnance inspector Daniel Joy conducted a sort of school for Pennsylvania ironmasters on the proper method of casting cannon. As a result, in 1776-77 approximately 100 'great guns' were cast at Hopewell Furnace and accepted by the Continental Navy.

On March 27, 1814, a deadly and decisive battle was waged at the Horseshoe Bend of the Tallapoosa River. Never before or since in the history of our country have so many Native Americans lost their lives in a single battle.
